description.narrative: The Philippines has relatively strong macroeconomic fundamentals, high local demand (102 million consumers), and steady economy growth (yearly 5/6%). A middle-class is developing and the demand for safe, quality and more convenient/luxury food products is rising fast. The undeveloped Filipino agriculture sector however is not yet able to supply this domestic demand. Generally, the Philippines agriculture sector has been neglected and has grown much slower than the overall economy; there have been significant problems with regard to inefficient production, agro-logistics and climate change adaptation and/or mitigation, among others. The Philippines is a net importer of food products and the domestic price level of food is quite high. In average people spend 40% of their household money for food. For poor people this is even higher.With the focus shift on sustainable development, the Embassy is interested on finding information regarding areas in the agri-food sector which would benefit from Dutch private sector involvement, which would lead into a “win-win” solution for the Netherlands and the PhilippinesThe study will be useful for the Embassy in promoting specific agri-food trade and investment opportunities in the Philippines that would benefit from Dutch expertise and technologies that are in line with the focus on sustainable development and inclusive growth. In addition the outcome of the study would provide the Ministry of Economic Affairs with additional information that can help in deciding whether or not to include the Philippines to the field of work of an Agricultural Counsellor. Special attention will be given to agribusiness policy issues as: veterinary/phytosanitary market access issues, Smart Climate Agriculture and Food Security.
